user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 17.8.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
The statement 'min_digits = 2;' assigns to the parameter min_digits (a non-pointer function parameter) inside MHD_uint8_to_str_pad. This modifies a function parameter and therefore violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. (Use a local copy, e.g. 'uint8_t min = min_digits;', and modify 'min' instead.)
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified MHD_uint8_to_str_pad code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/3742.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_uint8_to_str_pad:
```c
size_t
MHD_uint8_to_str_pad (uint8_t val,
                      uint8_t min_digits,
                      char *buf,
                      size_t buf_size)
{
  size_t pos; /**< the position of the current printed digit */
  int digit;
  mhd_assert (3 >= min_digits);
  if (0 == buf_size)
    return 0;

  pos = 0;
  digit = val / 100;
  if (0 == digit)
  {
    if (3 <= min_digits)
      buf[pos++] = '0';
  }
  else
  {
    buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) digit);
    val %= 100;
    min_digits = 2;
  }

  if (buf_size <= pos)
    return 0;
  digit = val / 10;
  if (0 == digit)
  {
    if (2 <= min_digits)
      buf[pos++] = '0';
  }
  else
  {
    buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) digit);
    val %= 10;
  }

  if (buf_size <= pos)
    return 0;
  buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) val);
  return pos;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified MHD_uint8_to_str_pad code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original MHD_uint8_to_str_pad with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as MHD_uint8_to_str_pad.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call MHD_uint8_to_str_pad to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of MHD_uint8_to_str_pad as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, MHD_uint8_to_str_pad will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of MHD_uint8_to_str_pad as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
